author: By Amanda Holpuch and Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: Mexico City Marathon Opens Investigation After Cheating Claims
description: In previous years, thousands of runners have been disqualified for course cutting. Runners are under scrutiny again.
content: The organizers of the Mexico City Marathon said they were investigating runners of the race last month for “unsportsmanlike” attitudes, after reports of people cheating emerged online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Carol Rosenberg
title: Biden Rejects Proposed Conditions for Plea Deals in Sept. 11 Case
description: Five Guantánamo detainees accused of aiding the attacks wanted a promise of care for torture-related trauma and to avoid solitary confinement.
content: President Biden has rejected a list of proposed conditions sought by the five men who are accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks in exchange for pleading guilty and receiving a maximum punishment of life in prison, according to two administration officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams and Anthony Cotsifas
title: In an Egyptian Oasis, a House Built From Sand, Rope and Salt
description: A designer and an environmentalist have created a retreat that surrenders to the desert.
content: WHEN INDIA MAHDAVI first began traveling to Egypt, she was in her late 20s and longing to connect with her ancestral origins. The architect and designer, now 61, was born in Tehran to an Egyptian mother and an Iranian father and grew up mainly in Cambridge, Mass.; Heidelberg, Germany; and Vence, France. “I was feeling like a plant in a pot that had eaten up all its earth,” she says. “I was all roots and no soil, craving for somewhere deeper to be planted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Explaining Bidenomics
description: What’s behind the shift in the Democratic Party’s economic policy?
content: Bill Clinton and Barack Obama both ran for president promising to reinvigorate the economy for ordinary Americans. And both enacted laws that helped millions of people. Clinton expanded children’s health care and tax credits for low-income families. Obama accomplished even more, making it possible for almost anybody to afford health insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: His Mind Helped Rebuild New York. His Body Is Failing Him.
description: Dan Doctoroff’s efforts to rebuild the city after 9/11 brought him power. A terrible diagnosis brought him peace.
content: The man pulls the buttoned blue shirt down over his head and waits. His hands, bony, cratered, have lost their strength, so the shirt flutters open at the sleeves and neck. His wife walks into the bedroom. She takes his left hand in hers, and closes the button around his wrist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: A Boogie That Stomps but Doesn’t Soar
description: Alexis Blake’s “Crack Nerve Boogie Swerve,” her first work to be shown in New York, focuses on strength and fragility.
content: Before the U.S. premiere of Alexis Blake’s “Crack Nerve Boogie Swerve” on Tuesday, they were handing out earplugs on the High Line in Lower Manhattan. At the elevated park’s 14th Street covered passage, you could choose how close to a bank of subwoofers you wanted to sit. Something loud and wild was about to happen, it seemed — an expectation heightened when a dancer entered carrying a hammer and began whacking a pane of glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Has India Changed Its Name? A G20 Invite Raises Eyebrows
description: Group of 20 leaders who’ll meet in India got a letter from the “President of Bharat,” a politically charged name for the country that’s popular with Hindu nationalists.
content: As India prepares to host the Group of 20 summit this week, the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi raised eyebrows  after an official invitation sent on behalf of the president used a different name for the country: Bharat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Scouts Honor’ Review: Uncovering a History of Abuse
description: This documentary, subtitled “The Secret Files of the Boy Scouts of America,” unveils the legacy organization’s habit of covering up cases of sexual abuse.
content: Almost three years ago, ahead of a bankruptcy court deadline, more than 82,000 people came forward with sexual abuse claims against the Boy Scouts of America. The mostly male survivors were of all ages and came from every state. Some of them had kept mum for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazeeha Saeed and Vivian Nereim
title: Mass Hunger Strike in Bahrain Prison Sets Off Rare Protests
description: In a kingdom that crushed an Arab Spring uprising more than a decade ago, prisoners are now on hunger strike to demand better conditions, fueling protests in support of their cause.
content: Rare street protests have broken out in Bahrain as a mass hunger strike enters its fifth week, activists say, in a faint echo of the uprising that swept the Gulf kingdom starting in 2011, during the Arab Spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo and Remy Tumin
title: Fatality Draws Scrutiny to Spicy ‘One Chip Challenge’ Product
description: Harris Wolobah, a 14-year-old in Worcester, Mass., died after he ate a Paqui brand tortilla chip dusted with two of the world’s hottest peppers, his mother said.
content: One of the last things Harris Wolobah, 14, of Worcester, Mass., ate before he died was a single tortilla chip in a coffin-shaped box that bore an image of a skull with a snake coiled around it, his mother said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: The Mystery Behind ‘A Wrinkle in Time’ Cover Art Is Solved
description: Sleuths have wondered for years who made a striking cover for Madeleine L’Engle’s novel. A podcast host and a blog writer who contacted hundreds of people figured it out.
content: For certain corners of the internet, a 1976 paperback edition of Madeleine L’Engle’s novel “A Wrinkle in Time” has been the source of an enduring mystery: Who was the artist behind its spooky, glowing-green cover art?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: To Make Fries Flawless, Big Farms Leave Some Homes Waterless
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 7, 2023.
content: “Think of our water supply as a giant milkshake glass and each well is a straw in the glass. What most states permit is a limitless number of straws in the glass.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Max Roach
description: The drummer helped pioneer bebop in the 1940s and delivered a message of resistance and liberation from the 1960s on. Listen to 13 selections from musicians, writers and critics.
content: For the past year, The New York Times has been asking musicians, writers and scholars to share the music they’d play for a friend to get them into jazz. Now we’re focusing on Max Roach, who, alongside the drummers Kenny Clarke and Art Blakey, helped pioneer bebop in the 1940s.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A.I. in the Classroom: What Should Teachers Do?
description: Responses to a tech column by Kevin Roose. Also: A Nobel physicist on the nature of the universe; Donald Trump’s jury; public funding for birth control.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: The Hunt for the Ideal Bánh Mì
description: Whether you’re in New Orleans, Tokyo or Paris, the perfect sandwich is waiting to be found.
content: I’m allergic to hyperbole, but it’s hard to think of a sandwich (to say nothing of a meal) more ideal than bánh mì. Hand-held, customizable and endlessly flavorful, each component checks a box: from the crispiest bread to a slathering of condiments (if you that’s how you take it) to the bánh mì’s litany of variable fillings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Andrew Rannells and Josh Gad Tackle Another Book (Not Mormon)
description: Twelve years after opening “The Book of Mormon,” the two actors — and good friends — return with “Gutenberg! The Musical!”
content: Josh Gad still remembers the first time he and Andrew Rannells met, in June 2010 in a Los Angeles audition suite. No matter what Gad did during their scenes together, Rannells didn’t laugh. Not once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Levitt
title: The 4 Arguments You Will Hear Against Drug Price Negotiation
description: Most Americans support lowering drug prices.
content: President Biden recently announced the first 10 drugs that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare. They include drugs to treat diabetes, heart disease, blood cancer, blood clots and rheumatoid arthritis — diseases that affect millions of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Joel Wolfram
title: With an Escaped Killer Loose, an Unsettling Encounter in a Darkened House
description: As the search for a convicted murderer continues, a mixture of fear and unease has settled over the community outside Philadelphia where he escaped and is believed to be hiding.
content: The French doors were cracked open to the night outside, and someone was down in the kitchen. Ryan Drummond, standing noiselessly at the top of the stairs, was sure he knew who it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Flooding From Cyclone in Southern Brazil Kills at Least 37
description: More than 3,500 people were displaced as towns flooded in the states of Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina. Rains were forecast to continue.
content: A cyclone battered southern Brazil early this week, killing at least 37 people, displacing 3,500 others and prompting the federal government to dispatch helicopters for rescues, the authorities said late Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump’s Next Defamation Trial Will Skip to What Damages He Should Pay
description: E. Jean Carroll’s suit is scheduled for a January trial. The judge ruled she did not have to prove a second time that Donald J. Trump defamed her after she accused him of raping her.
content: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a recent defamation lawsuit against former President Donald J. Trump, doesn’t have to prove again that he defamed her in another lawsuit she has filed against him when it goes to trial in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Sarah Wunsch, Dogged Defender of Civil Liberties, Dies at 75
description: Her advocacy in New York and Massachusetts won protections for free speech, gender equality and access to birth control. And she was a voice on marital rape.
content: Sarah Wunsch, a civil liberties lawyer who championed citizen protections on issues of race, gender and free speech and helped persuade New York’s highest court to declare that men could be prosecuted for raping their wives, died on Aug. 17 at her home in Brookline, Mass. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: A Love of Pomegranates, and a Perfect Baked Fish for Rosh Hashana
description: An artist’s love of the fruit has culminated in two galleries and a self-published book of recipes.
content: On entering Oded Halahmy’s Pomegranate Gallery in New York City, the bright red fruit is all you see: some fresh, others dried, several plump bronze ones on top of huge religious sculptures. There are even some sewn on the caps Mr. Halahmy, 85, wears, along with the phrase “pomegranate is love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: A Sculptor Breaks Through, Taking the Walls Down With Her
description: With powerfully alive new works at the Met and MoMA, the Iranian-born artist Nairy Baghramian embraces the canon, the better to take it apart.
content: Paris Bar, on Berlin’s Kantstrasse thoroughfare, is an old-school artist hangout, the kind of place where dealers hold court over chateaubriand and some distinguished elder painter commandeers the table you had reserved — which is what happened when Nairy Baghramian and I met there in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: With Aid on the Line, Biden Officials Debate ‘Coup’ Finding for Niger
description: American officials have tap danced around a word that would prompt a cutoff of U.S. assistance to a valued African ally.
content: For more than a month in Niger’s capital, Niamey, the democratically elected president has been a prisoner in his own home. The camouflage-clad generals who seized power say they may put him on trial. Talk of foreign intervention is met with threats of his execution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: They Love Tech. They’ve Got Money. Why Does Silicon Valley Ignore Old People?
description: What if technology companies seriously considered the problems of older customers?
content: Silicon Valley isn’t just consumed by youth; often, it’s blinded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $850,000 Homes in Texas, Michigan and Pennsylvania
description: A Tudor Revival house in Houston, an 1897 mansion in Cadillac and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Pittsburgh.
content: This house is in the Montrose neighborhood, a block off bustling Westheimer Road and within walking distance of a bakery and a vintage clothing store. Nearby dining options include a ramen bar, an Italian restaurant and a branch of the popular Jeni’s Splendid Ice Creams. Lanier Middle School is less than half a mile away; Lamar High School is a five-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Dignified Silence Doesn’t Work Against Trump
description: His opponents keep refusing to return his barbs, and are racking up political wounds.
content: Donald Trump is increasing his already overwhelming lead for the Republican nomination, and is tied with President Biden in a hypothetical general election face-off, according to recent polling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: histrionic
description: This word has appeared in 28 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word histrionic has appeared in 28 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 20 in “Tiago Rodrigues’s Theater of Compassion” by Laura Cappelle:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Rachel Chaundler
title: Spain Player Files Criminal Complaint Over Soccer Chief’s Kiss
description: Jennifer Hermoso has said the kiss from Luis Rubiales, head of the Spanish soccer federation, at the women’s World Cup was not consensual. The scandal has grown into a reckoning over sexism.
content: The Spanish soccer star Jennifer Hermoso has filed a sexual assault complaint against Luis Rubiales, the head of the country’s soccer federation, after he gave her an unsolicited kiss in the wake of her team’s World Cup victory in Australia last month, prosecutors said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Foster Kamer
title: Romy Madley Croft Is (Finally) Dancing on Her Own
description: The final member of the xx to release a solo album reveals her love of the pop club music of her teenage years, and her wife, on “Mid Air.”
content: As sheets of rain slammed a percussive beat on the skylights above her on a brisk April afternoon, Romy Madley Croft shook her head, smiling with the resignation of a seasoned professional wondering what kind of mess she’d gotten herself into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: To Win Big, Top Tennis Pros Turn to Marshmallows
description: Carlos Alcaraz is among the ranked players on the men’s and women's tours who have increasingly dared to use the drop shot on crucial points.
content: I thought I had seen it all on a tennis court until I watched Carlos Alcaraz at the U.S. Open on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Neighbors Are Illegally Breeding Dogs. Do I Report Them?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing animal welfare and a family’s need for income.
content: I live across the street from an apparently unregistered dog-breeding operation run by our neighbors. Our house looks out onto the yard where our neighbors let the dogs out sporadically throughout the day. The dogs don’t appear to be mistreated or malnourished, but there seem to be more than 26 total — exceeding the limit in our state for both owning and selling without a license. And they continuously breed the dogs. All of this occurs in a two-story city row home that also houses a family of six. So quarters must be tight; I would guess that the dogs spend a majority of the day in the basement, because that is the only conceivable space for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Why Republicans Could Impeach a Liberal Judge Before She’s Heard a Case
description: Republicans in Wisconsin have floated impeaching a newly seated liberal State Supreme Court justice who is threatening conservatives’ grip on state politics.
content: Republicans in Wisconsin are coalescing around the prospect of impeaching a newly seated liberal justice on the state’s Supreme Court, whose victory in a costly, high-stakes election this spring swung the court in Democrats’ favor and threatened the G.O.P.’s iron grip on state politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Pence Calls Trump’s Populism a ‘Road to Ruin’ for the G.O.P.
description: The former vice president used a speech in New Hampshire on Wednesday to call on Republicans to choose between conservatism and Donald Trump’s brand of populism.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence devoted an entire speech on Wednesday to what he called a “fundamental” and “unbridgeable” divide within the Republican Party — the split between Reaganite conservatives like himself and propagators of populism like former President Donald J. Trump and his imitators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Yasmin Marikar and Susan Wright
title: Where to Start in Emilia-Romagna?
description: The cheese, the pasta, the restaurants with Michelin stars? On a trip to this food-rich region of Italy, a writer’s checklist overflows with delicious options.
content: Tell people you are going to Emilia-Romagna, the food-rich region in northern Italy, and unsolicited recommendations follow: places to linger over pistachio ravioli and mortadella sandwiches, lasagna berberè and “really good” gelato.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: A Landmark Year for a Rare Calendar
description: After 60 years, the Italian tire company Pirelli hired a Black photographer to produce its not-for-sale calendar, which has evolved from a showcase of (scantily clad) bodies into a vehicle for ideas.
content: Wearing a gold strapless gown, Angela Bassett stood before two massive gilded doors while resting one hand on a giant key. She was standing inside a shallow makeshift pool that had been set up inside a heavily guarded photo studio on a muggy Thursday in June. Around the pool’s edges, assistants were crouched down and slapping the water with their hands to make waves that lapped at Ms. Bassett’s feet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Lonely at the Top
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 6, 2023.
content: “You’re not a guest. At all. You’re not their friend. At all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China’s Economic Pain Is a Test of Xi’s Fixation With Control
description: The slowdown is posing perhaps the most sustained challenge to President Xi Jinping’s agenda in over a decade in power. He now faces a tangle of difficult choices.
content: In Xi Jinping’s strategy for securing China’s rise, the Communist Party keeps a firm grip on the economy, steering it out of an old era dependent on real estate and smokestack industries to a new one driven by innovation and consumer spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: One of the Best Things We Can Do for Our Health Is Free — and Fun
description: Britain’s minister for loneliness offers a model of how to knit together a lonely crowd.
content: Loneliness crushes the soul, but researchers are finding it does far more damage than that. It is linked to strokes, heart disease, dementia, inflammation and suicide; it breaks the heart literally as well as figuratively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Accomplishments Are You Most Proud Of?
description: A guest writer argues that parents push kids too much to “achieve,” rather than allowing them to pursue their own goals. Do you agree?
content: What are your most memorable accomplishments? Mastering a difficult song on the piano? Getting a driver’s license? Learning to knit a scarf, shoot a layup or perform a dazzling magic trick?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: A possible advance by Ukraine’s army.
content: Ukrainian forces are battling to break through a Russian defense line in Ukraine’s south near the village of Verbove, military analysts said. The push comes a week after Ukrainian forces said they had retaken the village of Robotyne, the first of several tiers of formidable defenses that Russia has built in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Behold the Free Speech Chutzpah of the Republican Party
description: But that is only part of the problem.
content: A solid majority of Republicans continue to believe that Donald Trump won the 2020 election — evidence to the contrary notwithstanding. Virtually all Democrats believe that Trump did, in fact, lose the 2020 election and that Biden won fair and square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Making Electric-Car Chargers Faster (and Making Them Fit in Manhattan)
description: An entrepreneur confronts the challenges of bringing electric vehicles into wide use in New York City.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a former professor who’s now running a company that is designing and manufacturing chargers for electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and David Guttenfelder
title: In Jail, Writing in Short Bursts as Therapy and Performance Art
description: A former prosecutor found solace and renewal in a writing process he teaches to inmates in Minnesota.
content: Before handing pencil and paper to a group of inmates who attended one of his recent writing workshops in jail, Nate Johnson shared three things about his past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cory Doctorow
title: Burning Man Is Always a Challenge, but Burners Like Me Know This Time Is Different
description: The festival has to change, as does everything else.
content: Every time I go to Burning Man, there comes a moment when I ask myself, “Why did I choose this blazing, grueling workation when I could be back home, or on the beach?” By the end of the event, the answer is always clear — because there is nothing like it, anywhere on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Dependence on Tech Caused ‘Staggering’ Education Inequality, U.N. Agency Says
description: Heavy reliance on online remote learning during the pandemic drew attention away from more equitable ways of teaching children at home, a UNESCO report says.
content: In early 2020, as the coronavirus spread, schools around the world abruptly halted in-person education. To many governments and parents, moving classes online seemed the obvious stopgap solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Huawei Phone Is Latest Shot Fired in the U.S.-China Tech War
description: The release of a homegrown Chinese smartphone during a visit by the Biden official in charge of regulating such technology shows the U.S.-China tech conflict is alive and well.
content: In the midst of the U.S. commerce secretary’s good will tour to China last week, Huawei, the telecom giant that faces stiff U.S. trade restrictions, unveiled a smartphone that illustrated just how hard it has been for the United States to clamp down on China’s tech prowess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Fight for Your Kids’ Brains Has Already Begun
description: There’s a new threat to children’s freedom of thought from A.I. and neurotechnology.
content: Much of the drama in the charming new Netflix teen comedy “You Are So Not Invited to My Bat Mitzvah” revolves around the pitfalls of social media, specifically the public sharing of private videos. An early scene involves the heroine, Stacy, jumping off a cliff and into a lake to impress a bunch of cool kids, and while she does it, some of them start recording the moment on their phones. A mild spoiler: Stacy completes the jump without injury and to great applause, until her maxi pad floats up next to her and the applause dissolves into laughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Crispy, Chewy Rice Cake and Galbi Skewers to Send Off Grill Season
description: And a classic, simple salad that recalls summer nights in the south of France.
content: Despite my love for charred vegetables and steaks, I’m a fair-weather griller. If I lived in a more temperate climate, you’d probably find me kebabbing shrimp in the middle of January. But since I typically hang up my grill tongs as the autumn leaves fall, I think of these final summer weeks as one last, fiery hurrah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘The Battle of Chile’: Recalling the Other Sept. 11
description: Patricio Guzmán’s stunning three-part documentary is at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for a week, newly restored 50 years after the 1973 military coup.
content: “The Battle of Chile,” Patricio Guzmán’s 264-minute account of the social whirlwind that engulfed Salvador Allende’s socialist government in the early 1970s, is an epic documentary, an openly Marxist analysis and a stunning exercise in “you are there” vérité, not to mention a remarkable instance of contraband cinema — composed of footage smuggled out of fascist Chile and edited in communist Cuba to premiere at the radical fringe of the 1975 Cannes Film Festival (along with Chantal Akerman’s “Jeanne Dielman”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Mike Rogers, Former G.O.P. Representative, Will Run for Senate in Michigan
description: Mr. Rogers, who once led the House Intelligence Committee, is the most prominent Republican so far in the race to replace Senator Debbie Stabenow, a Democrat who is retiring.
content: Former Representative Mike Rogers of Michigan announced a campaign for an open Senate seat on Wednesday, giving Republicans a prominent candidate in an important swing-state race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle and Larry Fink
title: You Shouldn’t Have to Take Care of Your Aging Parents on Your Own
description: The help that caregivers need goes far beyond the nuts and bolts of caregiving and its financial costs.
content: Most people don’t like to think about growing old. But when asked, most Americans 55 or older say they want to do so at home. The appeal is understandable. Aging in place, surrounded by familiar places, faces and memories, can provide a sense of comfort and independence. It may seem a modest ambition, but the logistical and economic realities are daunting. Even healthy older people may struggle with basic tasks of daily life, so most of them will, at some point, require help from a caregiver, paid or unpaid, to remain at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: Men’s Tights Aren’t Just for Elizabethan Aristocrats Anymore
description: Stockings appeared on a slew of male models this season, once again affirming that their practical, provocative appeal transcends the gender binary.
content: AFTER SATIRIZING EVERYTHING from the western to the Stone Age, Mel Brooks in 1993 released the movie “Robin Hood: Men in Tights,” a sendup of “Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves,” which had come out two years earlier. Although Brooks’s parody was uniformly idiotic — Maid Marian wears an Everlast chastity belt; Blinkin, a blind servant, gropes a Braille edition of Playboy — many of the laughs were at the expense of so-called feygeles, a Yiddish slur for gay men. During a musical number with a cancan interlude, the heroic outlaw assures the audience he’s not one. “We may look like pansies,” he and his Merry Men sing, “but don’t get us wrong or else we’ll put out your lights. We’re men. We’re men in tights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: It’s One of Ukraine’s Fiercest Allies. But an Election Could Change That.
description: The vote in Slovakia this month will be a test of European unity on Ukraine, and of Russia’s efforts to undermine it. The front-runner wants to halt arms shipments to Kyiv.
content: When Ukraine discovered civilian mass graves in an area recaptured from Russian troops, Russia’s ambassador in neighboring Slovakia countered with his own discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: For Real
description: You won’t crack Blake Slonecker’s puzzle right away, and that’s good.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman and Sophia Alvarez Boyd
title: Paul Krugman’s Economic Advice to China: ‘Live a Little’
description: The Opinion columnist explains why the Chinese government needs to boost consumer spending to prevent an even worse economic situation.
content: China’s economic problems are growing: a real estate sector that’s going bankrupt, too many unemployed young workers and, remarkably, people saving too much. And, as the Nobel Prize-winning economist and Opinion columnist Paul Krugman argues in this audio essay, the Chinese government’s reluctance to encourage spending could make things worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: Loosen Your Tie for This Field Trip to Madison Square Garden
description: Fans of RBD, a Mexican telenovela pop act, flooded the arena with prep-school-inspired looks that nodded to the group’s source material and signature aesthetic.
content: In striped ties, white button-ups, denim skirts and red blazers, the crowds outside Madison Square Garden last week looked more ready for a field trip than a pop concert. But on Thursday (a school night!) and Friday, fans basked in nostalgia and welcomed the return of RBD, a 2000s pop act born out of a telenovela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Forcing Bulbs Isn’t Hard. So Why Don’t More People Try It?
description: Previous generations of gardeners knew that coaxing bulbs to bloom early was the easiest way to have fresh flowers in winter. Here’s how they did it.
content: Before Page Dickey and Francis Bosco Schell spent a single night in their house in northwestern Connecticut, clay pots of flower bulbs slumbered there, setting down roots in a space of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Rioters Have Been Held to Account. That Might Be the Easy Part.
description: With leaders of the far-right groups that helped drive the attack on the Capitol sentenced to long prison terms, attention is shifting to the fraught process of prosecuting Donald Trump.
content: When Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, was sentenced on Tuesday to 22 years in prison for his central role in planning the attack on the Capitol, it marked an inflection point in the Justice Department’s vast investigation of the events of Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Han Kang
title: Read Your Way Through Seoul
description: Han Kang grew up in Seoul, a city that embraces “thousands of years of turbulence.” She recommends reading that draws from the various eras that have made up her hometown.
content: Seoul is a megacity, with a population of nearly 10 million and a name pronounced like “soul.” There were times when I couldn’t stand its scale and pace of change, but I have managed to find a tranquil corner and continue to live in this city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Georgia Judge Says Two Defendants in Trump Case Will Get Early Trial Together
description: Sidney Powell followed Kenneth Chesebro in demanding a speedy trial, but neither defendant in the election interference case wanted to be tried with the other.
content: Two of Donald J. Trump’s co-defendants in the Georgia election-interference case will go to trial together on Oct. 23, a judge ruled on Wednesday. The defendants, Sidney Powell and Kenneth Chesebro, had asked to be tried separately from one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Georgia’s Ban on Transgender Care for Minors Takes Effect Again
description: A Georgia judge who had temporarily blocked the ban put her ruling on hold after a federal court struck down an injunction on a similar law in Alabama.
content: A federal judge in Georgia has allowed the state’s ban on gender transition care for minors to go back into full effect, after a federal appeals court panel allowed a similar law in Alabama to be enforced. Before the appellate ruling, the same judge, Sarah Geraghty, had granted a preliminary injunction that temporarily blocked part of the Georgia ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: New York City’s Lucrative No-Bid Migrant Services Contract Is Rejected
description: Brad Lander, the New York City comptroller, refused to approve the $432 million contract, questioning the qualifications of DocGo, the medical services company awarded the contract.
content: A no-bid $432 million contract that New York City officials gave to a medical services provider to house and care for migrants has been rejected by the New York City comptroller’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: TV Shows and Movies Streaming in September 2023: ‘The Wheel of Time,’ ‘Gen V’ and More
description: Spinoffs and chillers abound in a month filled with tons of new television. Here’s the best of what’s coming to Amazon, Max, Apple TV+ and others.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of September’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Carlos Prieto, Mary Wilson, Michael Simon Johnson, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rachel Quester, Patricia Willens, Will Reid, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
title: How 100,000 Migrants Became a Political Crisis in New York
description: The influx of asylum seekers could become a potent weapon against Democrats in congressional races next year.
content: In New York, the arrival of more than 100,000 migrants seeking asylum over the past year has become a crisis for the city’s shelter system, schools and budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn-Olaf Jones and Jack Healy
title: Burning Man’s Muddy Aftermath: A Desert Full of ‘Moop’
description: Cleaning up after the festival is always a challenge, but this year the trash is soaked with mud and trapped in hardening sludge.
content: After days of rain and mud, blocked exits and postponed parties, the last of Burning Man’s crowds trudged out of the Nevada desert on Wednesday morning. The “moop” remained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
title: In Its First Monopoly Trial of Modern Internet Era, U.S. Sets Sights on Google
description: The 10-week trial, set to begin Tuesday, amps up efforts to rein in Big Tech by targeting the core search business that turned Google into a $1.7 trillion behemoth.
content: The Justice Department has spent three years over two presidential administrations building the case that Google illegally abused its power over online search to throttle competition. To defend itself, Google has enlisted hundreds of employees and three powerful law firms and spent millions of dollars on legal fees and lobbyists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Prosecutors Rest Case Against Peter Navarro in Contempt Trial
description: The defense also rested, with closing arguments expected to begin Thursday morning. The fast clip of the trial suggested that the jury could deliberate shortly after.
content: Prosecutors rested their case on Wednesday in the criminal trial of Peter Navarro, who served as President Donald J. Trump’s trade adviser, saying he willfully ignored lawmakers in refusing to appear last year before the House committee investigating the Capitol attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Christopher Kuo
title: Rolling Stones Unveil ‘Hackney Diamonds’ in a Trendy London District
description: Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Ronnie Wood provided details about their first record of new material in 18 years, which will be released on Oct. 20.
content: When the Rolling Stones released “Beggars Banquet” in 1968, the band had an unusual way of grabbing attention: a surprise food fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration to Bar Drilling on Millions of Acres in Alaska
description: The administration will cancel oil and gas leases in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and set aside more than half of the National Petroleum Reserve.
content: In its most aggressive move yet to protect federal land from oil and gas exploration, the Biden administration announced on Wednesday that it would prohibit drilling in 13 million acres of pristine wilderness in the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska and cancel all drilling leases in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: After 3 Weeks of Wildfire Exile, a City of 20,000 Returns
description: The residents of Yellowknife, the capital of the Northwest Territories of Canada, were ordered out last month when a wildfire came near their city.
content: Twenty-two days after they were evacuated from the capital of the Northwest Territories in the face of a racing wildfire, the roughly 20,000 residents of Yellowknife began returning home on Wednesday to refrigerators filled with spoiled food to restart their lives in a city that averted disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Ben Shelton Advances to U.S. Open Semifinal Against Novak Djokovic
description: Shelton, 20, becomes the youngest American man to reach a U.S. Open semifinal since Andy Roddick in 2003.
content: There was a time when a U.S. Open quarterfinal match between two big-hitting American men could just be referred to as “tennis,” rather than as a historic night for the sport in this country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: As Abortion Laws Drive Obstetricians From Red States, Maternity Care Suffers
description: Some doctors who handle high-risk pregnancies are fleeing restrictive abortion laws. Idaho has been particularly hard hit.
content: One by one, doctors who handle high-risk pregnancies are disappearing from Idaho — part of a wave of obstetricians fleeing restrictive abortion laws and a hostile state legislature. Dr. Caitlin Gustafson, a family doctor who also delivers babies in the tiny mountain town of McCall, is among those left behind, facing a lonely and uncertain future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Gary Wright, Who Had a ’70s Hit With ‘Dream Weaver,’ Dies at 80
description: He was a pioneer in using synthesizers, and his friendship with George Harrison led to a spiritual awakening that also influenced another hit, “Love Is Alive.”
content: Gary Wright, a spiritually minded singer-songwriter who helped modernize the sound of pop music with his pioneering use of synthesizers while crafting infectious and seemingly inescapable hits of the 1970s, notably “Dream Weaver” and “Love Is Alive,” died on Monday at his home in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Turns to a Steady Old Hand to Fight Antitrust Charges
description: The tech giant is facing the greatest legal threat in its history, and hopes the stolid approach of Kent Walker, its top lawyer, will once again prevail.
content: When the government started an antitrust investigation into Google, one of the company’s top lawyers, Kent Walker, said the solution was not a charm offensive. Google just needed to explain how its business functioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: After Primary, Rhode Island Looks Set to Have Its First Black Member of Congress
description: Gabriel Amo, a moderate Democrat who served in the Obama and Biden administrations, won a special House primary to succeed Representative David N. Cicilline in the deep-blue state.
content: Gabriel Amo, a moderate Democrat who served in the Biden and Obama administrations, won a raucous Democratic special primary election in Rhode Island’s First Congressional District on Tuesday, positioning him to become the first person of color to represent the state in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Forests Are No Longer Our Climate Friends
description: Wildfires pump greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and carbon offsets are no longer looking effective.
content: Canadian wildfires have this year burned a land area larger than 104 of the world’s 195 countries. The carbon dioxide released by them so far is estimated to be nearly 1.5 billion tons — more than twice as much as Canada releases through transportation, electricity generation, heavy industry, construction and agriculture combined. In fact, it is more than the total emissions of more than 100 of the world’s countries — also combined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta, Lynsey Addario and Constant Méheut
title: At a Bustling Market in Ukraine, a Huge Fireball Leaves Scenes of Carnage
description: A Russian missile strike in Kostyantynivka that killed at least 17 and injured more than 30 others was one of the deadliest in months.
content: When Vadym Zgonnik was walking through the outdoor market in Kostyantynivka, Ukraine, with his wife and 6-year-old daughter on Wednesday afternoon, it was at first a bustling scene much like any other afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: The Nets Are Up in Flushing Meadows. But Not for the Sport You Think.
description: Just outside the U.S. Open grounds, Queens locals, many of them immigrants from Ecuador, play a volleyball-like sport imported from their country that brings the community together.
content: Each summer, Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens hosts one of the most distinct, continually functioning sporting events in New York City. It features hundreds of players hitting balls, delicious food on offer and spectators sipping drinks while soaking in the entertainment. And on the other side of a fence, there is also a tennis tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘Portrait of the Queen’ Review: Seeking Fresh Angles on a Familiar Face
description: This documentary attempts to give a unique look at Queen Elizabeth II by speaking to photographers who took portraits of her.
content: Endless is the stream of programs that have, over the last 70 years, documented the life of Queen Elizabeth II. Yet “Portrait of the Queen” takes on a unique angle, examining the creation of the queen’s public image by, in its most effective moments, speaking to a handful of photographers who have taken her portrait throughout her reign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler, Sarah Hurtes and Jeré Longman
title: Bedtime Check-Ins and Verbal Abuse: Women’s Life in Spanish Soccer
description: More than a dozen women described sexism ranging from paternalism to verbal abuse. “What you really need is a good man,” a former national captain said players were told.
content: Last summer, when Beatriz Álvarez landed the job as president of the Spanish women’s soccer league, she asked to meet the chief of the country’s soccer federation by videoconference, she said, so she could remain home with her newborn child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Florida Expected to Approve Classical Exam as a Competitor to the SAT
description: The Classic Learning Test emphasizes the Western canon and Christian thought. It’s the latest move by Gov. Ron DeSantis to shake up the education establishment.
content: The Classic Learning Test is the college admissions exam that most students have never heard of. An alternative to the SAT and ACT for only a small number of mostly religious colleges, the test is known for its emphasis on the Western canon, with a big dose of Christian thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teri Agins
title: Powered by A.I., Company Aims to Make Selling Easier for Retailers
description: Lily AI matches online shoppers to the merchandise they’re looking for based on colloquial search terms, a welcome change for companies like Bloomingdale’s.
content: When Danielle Schmelkin went shopping online for something special to wear to her niece’s wedding in 2021, she was looking for “a very specific type of dress based on trends I had seen recently.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: In Mexico, Drug Trade Flourished With the Help of the State
description: An article sheds light on a notorious cold case.
content: It was, even by the usual high standards of New York Times investigations, an article that took my breath away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Constant Méheut
title: As Blinken Visits Kyiv to Show Support, Russia Makes a Deadly Attack
description: A Russian missile killed at least 17 civilians and wounded dozens, while Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken vowed lasting backing and announced a new round of aid.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken traveled to Ukraine’s capital on Wednesday and met with President Voloydmyr Zelensky, delivering a U.S. vote of confidence — and the promise of more aid — even as Russia made one of the deadliest attacks of the war on civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Colorado Lawsuit Seeks to Keep Trump Off Ballots Under 14th Amendment
description: The amendment says anyone who “engaged in insurrection or rebellion” against the Constitution after taking an oath to defend it is ineligible to hold office, and a long-shot effort to employ it is growing.
content: Six Colorado voters filed a lawsuit on Wednesday seeking to keep former President Donald J. Trump off the state’s ballots under the 14th Amendment, which says anyone who “engaged in insurrection or rebellion” against the Constitution after taking an oath to defend it is ineligible to hold office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How to Interpret Polling Showing Biden’s Loss of Nonwhite Support
description: Yes, there’s reason for skepticism, but also reason for concern for Democrats, particularly over turnout.
content: Is President Biden really struggling as badly among nonwhite voters — especially Black voters — as the polls say?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At the U.S. Open, Stifling Heat Causes Some Players to Lose Their Cool
description: An unseasonal stretch of extreme heat and humidity has left the stadiums at the Open sweltering. But a few players, Coco Gauff among them, say the hotter, the better.
content: In most years, there is a very specific climate pattern at the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Fall’s Go-To Accessories, in Shades of Olive
description: Neutral green carryalls and loafers complement any outfit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Suspected Russian drone debris is found in Romania.
description: The Romanian president, Klaus Iohannis, said that if the wreckage was confirmed to be Russian, it would be “a serious violation” of a NATO member’s sovereignty.
content: Romania said on Wednesday that debris from what could be a Russian drone had landed on its territory across the Danube River from Ukraine and said that if the wreckage turned out to be Russian, it would be “a serious violation” of a NATO member’s sovereignty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: Alabama Cherishes Its History of Defying the Federal Courts
description: Alabama’s resistance to the Supreme Court’s voting rights decision recalls its similar stand against school integration in 1954.
content: Most other states would be ashamed of the tongue lashing issued against the government of Alabama on Tuesday by a trio of federal judges, all of whom were clearly furious that the state ignored their order to create a second majority-Black congressional district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Queen Lyrics and Freddie Mercury’s Grand Piano Soar at Auction
description: Sotheby’s in London began selling about 1,400 items once owned by the charismatic lead singer, who was also a discriminating collector of woodblock prints and other Japanese art.
content: It started at 40,000 pounds, or about $50,000. Then the competition exploded, with a half-dozen bidding paddles raised in the London salesroom, followed by a flurry of bids online and by phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella Kwai
title: Extreme Rains Cause Flooding in Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, Killing 14
description: The floodwaters ravaged bridges, stranded tourists and swept away cars and buildings. Thousands of households were still cut off from power on Wednesday.
content: Violent storms have pounded parts of Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey with extreme amounts of rain, causing floods that killed at least 14 people, ravaged roads and prompted evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Ex-Leader of Proud Boys Is Sentenced, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Why the G20 Keeps Failing, and Still Matters
description: Summits like the one in India this weekend have produced many ambitious statements — and, often, disappointing results. Critics say an upgrade is needed.
content: The annual Group of 20 summit brings together world leaders in pursuit of a lofty goal: coordinating policy for the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How America Made James Bond ‘Woke’
description: Why wokeness seems so powerful in Britain and Canada.
content: After so many decades fighting evil masterminds bent on Britannia’s destruction, the 21st-century version of James Bond has found a very 21st-century antagonist. In the newest Bond novel, “On His Majesty’s Secret Service,” 007 is charged with protecting King Charles III from a dastardly plot hatched by a supervillain whose nom de guerre is Athelstan of Wessex — in other words, a Little Englander, a Brexiteer, a right-wing populist, apparently the true and natural heir to Goldfinger and Blofeld.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: $100 Oil? What a Price Spike Could Mean for Markets and Geopolitics
description: Analysts see Brent crude climbing to levels last seen in the first months of the Ukraine war after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended production cuts.
content: Brent crude oil was trading on Wednesday morning at around $90 a barrel for the second straight day, and is up 25 percent since June thanks to the prospect of more production cuts by leading oil exporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Judge Blocks Transgender Notification Policy in California School District
description: The state attorney general had sued the Chino Valley Unified School District and said its policy could lead to “forced outing.”
content: A superior court judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked a Southern California school district from notifying parents if their child seeks to change pronouns or gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 6, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 6, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about over-the-counter availability of Narcan misstated the number of overdose deaths in the previous two years in the United States. There were more than 100,000 drug overdose deaths in all each year, higher than the number attributable to opioids alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanam Yar
title: Beyoncé Fuels a Small-Business Boom
description: When the performer asked fans to wear silver for Virgo season, shops on Etsy and elsewhere saw the collective spending power of the BeyHive.
content: When Virgo season dawned, Beyoncé — perhaps the world’s most famous Virgo, who named a track on her seventh album, “Renaissance,” after the star sign — had a birthday request.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marissa R. Moss
title: Tyler Childers Puts His Own Spin on Heartfelt Rural Anthems
description: The country musician has sung about racial violence and made a video depicting a queer love story. His new album, “Rustin’ in the Rain,” was inspired by his roots — and Elvis Presley.
content: There are parts of Kentucky where the ground is pruned and prettied, and there are parts where the grass just grows. During the early days of his career, Tyler Childers had one foot in both — as a kid from rural Lawrence County doing landscape work for a Lexington mill while he played country music for whoever would listen. One night, his worlds converged. Asked to perform at the office Christmas party, he dressed up in a tie and good shoes. He thought he looked sharp until an older man stopped to crack a joke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Ellen Barry
title: At Yale, a Surge of Activism Forced Changes in Mental Health Policies
description: For decades, the university required students seeking medical leaves to withdraw and reapply. A campus suicide set off a cascade of revisions.
content: In the weeks after Rachael Shaw-Rosenbaum, a first-year student at Yale, died by suicide in 2021, a group of strangers began convening on Zoom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Naomi Osaka Makes U.S. Open Return. But Not for Tennis.
description: Osaka, the four-time Grand Slam singles champion, has taken breaks from tennis for her mental health and to start a family, but she is aiming to compete again in 2024.
content: Naomi Osaka didn’t bring any rackets with her when she arrived at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center on Wednesday afternoon. Osaka had no plans to play tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adlan Jackson
title: How Pop Stars Turned NPR’s ‘Tiny Desk’ Into Authenticity Theater
description: The concerts have become an incongruous draw for pop stars with something to prove.
content: What does anyone stand to gain from a string quartet accompanying Post Malone? At one of the megastar’s typical performances, you might find Austin Post standing alone on a vast stage, shirtless, mimicking the postures you might see at a rapper’s show, warbling his melodic pop with its intermittent hip-hop gestures. Recently, though, the singer sat down on the set of NPR’s Tiny Desk concert series — in an unassuming, tchotchke-filled corner of a Washington office — to perform a handful of his songs with a larger ensemble: 12 musicians, including four backup vocalists and four string players, rearranging his hits to highlight multipart harmonies and the twinkle of acoustic instruments. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Nigerian Court Rejects Challenges to Contested Presidential Election
description: The tribunal confirmed the election of President Bola Tinubu, who has faced growing discontent amid unpopular economic policies and lingering allegations of irregularities in the election.
content: A judicial tribunal in Nigeria confirmed on Wednesday the results of a contested February presidential election that kept Africa’s most populous country on edge amid allegations of voting irregularities and tainted the first months in power for the declared winner, President Bola Tinubu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Is That an Asterisk Next to Breanna Stewart’s Points Record?
description: She has scored more points this season than anyone else in W.N.B.A. history, but had more games to do it.
content: Breanna Stewart of the Liberty has now scored more points than any other player in a single season in W.N.B.A. history. But is she really the league’s best scorer ever? It depends on how you look at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Says It Will Indict Hunter Biden on Gun Charge This Month
description: The timetable, following the collapse of an earlier deal that would have allowed President Biden’s son to avoid any jail time, means he will face prosecution as his father seeks re-election.
content: David C. Weiss, the special counsel investigating Hunter Biden, said on Wednesday that he planned to indict the president’s son on a gun charge before the end of the month — a move prompted by the acrimonious collapse of a plea deal in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Former Top Deputy Says Ken Paxton Took Unusual Actions to Help Donor
description: The former aide, Jeff Mateer, testified for a second day in Mr. Paxton’s impeachment trial, describing feelings of alarm and betrayal.
content: The second day of the impeachment trial of Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas on Wednesday featured the heart of the case against him: how his interventions on behalf of a local real estate investor so disturbed the Republican lawyers who were his top aides that they became whistle-blowers against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Fauzia
title: What Goes Up a Tree Must Evolve the Ability to Climb Down
description: In a study of chimpanzee and monkey anatomy, primate arms provide hints about how our ancestors got to the ground in one piece.
content: Millions of years ago, a simian ancestor of humanity decided to climb a tree. It may have been looking for a meal, escaping a predator or seeking a shady place to rest. Later, like anyone who has ascended high into a forest’s canopy, our relative discovered that getting down in one piece is less simple than it seems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: British Bees Face a Deadly Invasion
description: The number of sightings of Asian hornets, an invasive species that can wipe out bee colonies, has spiked this year, raising concerns among British beekeepers.
content: A sharp increase in the number of an invasive species of hornets in Britain is raising concerns that they could threaten native bee populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Jessica Lange Leads Starry Cast of New Paula Vogel Play on Broadway
description: “Mother Play,” set in the 1960s, will feature Lange as a mother raising two children, played by Jim Parsons and Celia Keenan-Bolger.
content: Jessica Lange, Jim Parsons and Celia Keenan-Bolger will return to Broadway next spring to star in a new family drama by the acclaimed playwright Paula Vogel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ferid Murad, Nobelist Who Saw How a Gas Can Aid the Heart, Dies at 86
description: An American pharmacologist, he delved into the effects of nitric oxide, work that led to advances in treating heart disease, hypertension and erectile dysfunction.
content: Ferid Murad, a pharmacologist whose research into the effects of nitric oxide on the heart and blood vessels enabled widespread advancements in the treatment of cardiovascular disease, hypertension and erectile dysfunction, and which earned him a share in a Nobel Prize in 1998, died on Monday at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Judge Orders Texas to Move Barrier From Middle of the Rio Grande
description: A federal judge ordered the state to move the barrier, placed to discourage illegal crossings from Mexico, to the banks of the river.
content: A federal judge ordered Gov. Greg Abbott on Wednesday to move a barrier of floating buoys in the Rio Grande that was placed by the state of Texas to discourage illegal crossings from Mexico, concluding that it was an impediment to navigation on the river and a “threat to human life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller and Kenneth Chang
title: Japan Joins the New Moon Race, and Launches an X-Ray Telescope, Too
description: The telescope will help astronomers study some of the most energetic places in the cosmos, while the lunar mission will aid the development of pinpoint moon landing technologies.
content: On Thursday morning in Japan, a bus-size telescope with X-Ray vision soared into space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Mexico’s Supreme Court Decriminalizes Abortion Nationwide
description: The decision builds on an earlier high court ruling and reflects how Latin American countries are expanding women’s rights.
content: Mexico’s Supreme Court decriminalized abortion nationwide on Wednesday in a sweeping decision that builds on an earlier ruling giving officials the authority to allow the procedure on a state-by-state basis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: 80,000 Students With One Dilemma: Will N.Y.C. School Bus Workers Strike?
description: New York City public schools start on Thursday, as union leaders and school bus companies are locked in contract negotiations.
content: As New York City students prepare to return to their classrooms on Thursday, a major question remains unsettled for tens of thousands of families: Will their children have yellow bus service to and from school this fall?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Lipkin and Hisato Tasaka
title: This Fall, Men’s Tailoring Gets a High-Tech Update
description: Sporty textures add modern energy to classic shirts and suits.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): ‘Bottoms,’ ‘Hard Knocks’ & Uncovering Rap History
description: What we watched (and read!) this summer.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Terence Blanchard, Pushing Jazz Forward From a New Perch
description: The trumpeter and composer follows the premiere of two Met operas with an appointment as executive artistic director of SFJazz in San Francisco and a Jazz Masters honor.
content: Two big announcements came down recently about the trumpeter and composer Terence Blanchard — both monumental, neither one a surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Police Hunt Terror Suspect Who Escaped London Prison
description: A former British Army soldier, Daniel Abed Khalife, broke out of prison while awaiting trial on charges of breaking the Official Secrets Act and terrorism-related offenses.
content: A former British Army soldier facing terrorism-related charges escaped from a prison in southwest London on Wednesday morning, prompting a nationwide manhunt by the police, who appealed to the public for help apprehending him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Fall Video Games
description: Which new releases are you most excited about? Why?
content: The coming months are “stacked with AAA releases, long-awaited sequels and promising independent games,” writes The Times in its preview, “12 Video Games Releasing This Fall.” That includes additions to the Mortal Kombat, Super Mario Bros. and Assassin’s Creed franchises — and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How to Make American Health Care Cheaper and Better
description: To help patients and reduce costs, the U.S. health care system needs more innovation, two experts argue.
content: James and Robert Rebitzer are identical twins who enjoy each other’s company. “We talk. We talk a lot,” Bob said in a video interview I did with the two of them recently. “We’re kind of like the Three Stooges. Once we get going we just amuse each other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: At Africa’s First Climate Summit, a Clear Call to the World: Invest in Us
description: The inaugural summit in Kenya’s capital, attended by tens of thousands, was imbued with frustration at Western financial institutions.
content: Heads of state from across Africa concluded an inaugural climate summit on Wednesday in Nairobi, Kenya’s capital, by issuing a declaration that called for an urgent restructuring of the way wealthier nations engage with the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The U.S. Will Send $1 Billion More to Ukraine
description: Also, a new Rolling Stones album. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: During a visit to Kyiv, Secretary of State Antony Blinken today announced more than $1 billion in new American aid to Ukraine. He was the highest-profile American official to visit the country since the beginning of Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Comcast and Disney Agree to Speed Up Hulu Deal
description: Disney is poised to own the entirety of the Hulu streaming service, which has more than 48 million total subscribers.
content: The tug of war over Hulu, one of the world’s most popular streaming services, might be over sooner than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California Democrats Want Courts to Let Cities Clear Homeless Camps
description: Five years after a federal court restricted cities in the West from removing homeless campers, Democratic leaders are blaming judges for the growing number of people living on the streets.
content: Five years ago in San Francisco, a federal appeals court upended homeless policy in California and across the West. In a 2018 ruling against the city of Boise, Idaho, the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit said that cities could not enforce local laws against outdoor camping if they didn’t offer enough shelter beds for people living on the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: As Car Thefts Soar, N.Y.P.D. Targets Teenage Thieves
description: The police will designate a patrol car in each precinct to track stolen cars, and officials said half of those arrested in the thefts were under 18.
content: The Police Department will designate one patrol car in each of New York City’s 77 precincts to trace stolen vehicles, as car theft continues to rise even as the rate of most other major crimes in the city is falling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: U.K. Flight Chaos Was a ‘One in 15 Million’ Problem, Controllers Say
description: Air traffic computer systems shut down after receiving duplicate data, a report found, forcing plans to be processed manually.
content: The technical failure that led to hundreds of flight cancellations and severe disruptions for thousands of people traveling in and out of Britain last week resulted from a “one in 15 million chance,” the country’s air traffic control service said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: WeWork Declares Intent to Renegotiate Almost All Leases
description: A month after saying its continued existence was in doubt, the co-working company says it expects to “exit unfit and underperforming locations.”
content: After WeWork warned last month that it might not be in business for much longer, its chief executive said on Wednesday that the co-working company was going to try to renegotiate nearly all of its leases and would probably pull out of underperforming locations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Mark Felix
title: America’s Fire Spotters Aren’t Ready to Fade Away Just Yet
description: Officials say the future of wildfire detection is cameras. But in northwest Montana, solitary humans on mountaintops still do more than machines alone can offer.
content: If, on a hot, dry day a fire should break out within a certain 300,000-acre patch of northwest Montana, in an expanse of backcountry between the crest of the Whitefish Range and the glacier-carved peaks that hug the Continental Divide, there’s a good chance Leif Haugen will be the first person on Earth to see it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Wife and I Were Abandoned for the Holidays. Help!
description: After his mother agreed to host him and his wife for Christmas, a reader is hurt by her decision to spend the holiday itself with her daughter instead.
content: My mother-in-law has been more and more stressed when my wife and I have visited for Christmas the past few years. We’re not sure why, and she won’t talk about it. So, we called my folks around Dec. 27 last year and asked if we could spend this Christmas with them. They said they were delighted. Then in June, my mom told us she wanted to celebrate early, on Dec. 22, so she could fly to California to spend the actual holiday with my sister and her kids. We said this was not what we had in mind. My dad agreed with us, but she held firm. We still plan to fly there and spend the holiday with my brother’s family and my grandfather, but we’re hurt. We reached out when we were feeling low, and then my mother changed plans on us at the last minute. Your thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: McConnell, Dismissing Health Questions, Insists He Will Continue as Leader
description: The Kentucky Republican said he would finish his term as leader, which runs through 2024, and in the Senate, where he was elected to serve through 2026.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the longtime Republican leader whose recent medical episodes have raised questions about his ability to continue steering his party in the Senate, declared on Wednesday that he had no intention of relinquishing his top post or leaving Congress ahead of schedule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Magic of the Granny Flat
description: Cities are experimenting with a promising tool for addressing a critical shortage of housing for older Americans.
content: About a decade ago, Megan Parrish began worrying about her mother, Pat Dalrymple. Ms. Dalrymple, now 68, was living alone in Lake Arrowhead, a mountainous resort area in California, and her house was becoming too much for her to handle. “I knew Mom was having a hard time,” Ms. Parrish recalled. So she floated the idea of her mother moving to be near her and her husband, Sam. Soon the three of them were in search of a way to keep Ms. Dalrymple close — but not too close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Thursday Briefing: Blinken Visits Kyiv
description: Plus, the deadliest missile attack in Ukraine in months.
content: At least 17 people were killed yesterday in a Russian strike on Kostyantynivka, a city in eastern Ukraine that is close to the front lines, President Volodymyr Zelensky said. The attack, one of the deadliest strikes in Ukraine in months, came hours after the U.S. secretary of state, Antony Blinken, arrived in Kyiv for an unannounced visit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It’s Fun to Be Alive’: 13 Older Photographers Show Us Their Work — and Themselves
description: We asked renowned photographers to show us when and where they feel most seen. It’s a different lens on growing older.
content: We asked renowned photographers to show us when and where they feel most seen. It’s a different lens on growing older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ziegler
title: Ben Shelton Is Dialed In
description: The rising star has a way to show the world that he's on his game.
content: The rising star has a way to show the world that he's on his game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: What’s in Our Queue? Rebecca Donner and More
description: I’m the bureau chief for Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean. Here are five things I've been reading, watching, listening to and playing.
content: I’m the bureau chief for Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean. Here are five things I've been reading, watching, listening to and playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: America Is Growing Old. We Look Into Its Future.
description: It’s time for the country to have an honest conversation about aging.
content: It’s time for the country to have an honest conversation about aging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: 5-Minute Morning Yoga
description: Seven poses to help you wake up and feel energized, whether you’re an expert or a beginner.
content: Seven poses to help you wake up and feel energized, whether you’re an expert or a beginner.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s What It’s Like to Take the Classic Learning Test
description: Florida’s public university system is expected to approve the Classic Learning Test for college admissions, an alternative to the SAT or ACT.
content: Florida’s public university system is expected to approve the Classic Learning Test for college admissions, an alternative to the SAT or ACT.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Hong
title: The City Looks Different When You’re Older
description: Cracked sidewalks, fast cars, nowhere to sit — it’s hard to navigate the streets when you’re older. But it doesn’t have to be.
content: Cracked sidewalks, fast cars, nowhere to sit — it’s hard to navigate the streets when you’re older. But it doesn’t have to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Associated Press
title: Deadly Floodwaters Submerge Brazil’s South
description: Volunteers held hands to create a human chain and pull in boats carrying people rescued from the floods.
content: Volunteers held hands to create a human chain and pull in boats carrying people rescued from the floods.
source.name: The New York Times
